member.name: WS_FAULT
member.summary: A Fault is a value carried in the body of a message which conveys a processing failure. Faults are modeled using the WS_FAULT structure.

member.name: WS_FAULT.code
member.summary:
The head of the list of fault codes which identifies the type of fault.
The fault codes are ordered from most generic to most specific. There must be at least one fault code. The first fault code must correspond to a fault code defined by SOAP. For , only the most specific fault code is serialized (the first one in the list).

The appropriate SOAP namespace will be used based on the .
If the local name is "Sender" when using , then "Client" will be used instead.
If the local name is "Receiver" when using , then "Server" will be used instead.
These transformations allow a SOAP fault code to be specified without having to worry about which SOAP version is used.

member.name: WS_FAULT.reasons
member.summary: The text describing the fault. This is an array to allow for different languages.

summary.para: The number of reasons in the reasons array. This would be more than one if the text was represented in multiple languages. There must be at least one fault reason.
For , only the first reason is serialized.

member.name: WS_FAULT.actor
member.summary: The name of the processor that caused the fault. If the string is zero length, then it's assumed to be the endpoint.

summary.para: The location of the processor that caused the fault. If the string is zero length, then it's assumed to be the endpoint.
For , this value is not serialized.
The fault detail allows for XML content to be included along with the fault. If there is no detail, then this field may be NULL.
For , this should only be used if the fault does not relate to processing of a header of the message. Faults relating to headers should use a custom header to relay information about the fault.

If there is detail for the fault, the WS_XML_BUFFER should contain an element that corresponds to the detail element of a SOAP fault. The fault-specific XML content is contained within the detail element. The local name and namespace of the element are ignored; they are replaced with the appropriate element name according to the when the detail element is written.
